Erik Wilde (@dret): Making APIs the Default: Enabling Everybody to Think the API Way

(2) Summary

APIs are much more than technology. It becomes increasingly apparent that by only focusing on their technology aspects, you're missing out on the biggest opportunities that APIs create for your organization and your business. In our work with large organizations we have realized that one essential aspect of realizing the value proposition of APIs is to API-enable all of the organization. This is particularly important for product managers, who need to start thinking about every single product of an organization as a digital building block. We present our way of how we make sure that "Thinking the API Way" becomes the default for everybody in the line of business. Because in the end, the value of APIs critically depends on how much of an organization's business and value chains are exposed using APIs. Only then it becomes possible to benefit from the loose coupling and the increased velocity that APIs can deliver.

Why: The Business Value of APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): Making APIs the Default: Enabling Everybody to Think the API Way

(7) Organizations Need Adaptation

  • In most domains the world changes faster than it used to
    • Organizations need to be good at adapting to changing constraints
    • It must be easy to build, launch, modify, reuse, and discontinue products
  • APIs are what turns digital products into digital building blocks
    • APIs make it relatively easy to reconfigure digital value chains
    • It still takes the right business strategy to keep up with changes


Why: The Business Value of APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): Making APIs the Default: Enabling Everybody to Think the API Way

(8) What is a Product?



Why: The Business Value of APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): Making APIs the Default: Enabling Everybody to Think the API Way

(9) API Value = Propositions × Scope

Digitalization
(Internal) [Scope #1: Digitalization (1)]		 API Economy
(External) [Scope #2: API Economy (1)]
Collaboration [API Value #1: Collaboration (1)] Loosely coupled teams Ease of building value chains
Innovation [API Value #2: Innovation (1)] Creative ways of reusing building blocks New ways of composing value chains
Co-Creation [API Value #3: Co-Creation (1)] Reuse without coordination Sharing value with platform partners

API Value Propositions Erik Wilde (@dret): Making APIs the Default: Enabling Everybody to Think the API Way

(11) API Value #1: Collaboration

  • All teams produce potential for collaboration
  • Teams can collaborate without coordination
  • Product inception and design are incrementally building on existing capabilities


API Value Propositions Erik Wilde (@dret): Making APIs the Default: Enabling Everybody to Think the API Way

(12) API Value #2: Innovation

  • New products can be created because building blocks are openly available
  • Products can co-exist and compete with value generation being a useful metric


API Value Propositions Erik Wilde (@dret): Making APIs the Default: Enabling Everybody to Think the API Way

(13) API Value #3: Co-Creation

  • Products can be improved by building on them as building blocks
  • Products can share building blocks and create value differently
  • Value chains can be improved by strengthening weak components


API Value Scope

Outline (API Value Scope)

  1. Introduction [2]
  2. Why: The Business Value of APIs [13]

API Value Scope Erik Wilde (@dret): Making APIs the Default: Enabling Everybody to Think the API Way

(15) Scope #1: Digitalization

  • Internal API focus often requires fundamental changes
  • Products are ephemeral and the true focus is the platform they're built on
    • Every product must be built so that it can be built on
    • No product gets to take shortcuts when consuming or exposing APIs
  • Every product becomes an API product in a truly digitalized organization


API Value Scope Erik Wilde (@dret): Making APIs the Default: Enabling Everybody to Think the API Way

(16) Scope #2: API Economy

  • External API focus is about how to use partner/public APIs
  • API monetization often plays a role in these discussions
    • Direct monetization is more the exception than the rule
    • Indirect monetization means driving value by strategically using APIs
  • Internal/external API is a perspective that can change over time

(24) Product Delivery



What: Products as APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): Making APIs the Default: Enabling Everybody to Think the API Way

(25) Product Marketing Mix: 4 Ps

  • Framework for decision-making for product marketing
    • Product: Good or service wanted by consumers
    • Price: What are consumers willing to pay for the product?
    • Place: How to make products available to consumers
    • Promotion: How to make consumers aware of products
  • Applying the 4 P model to the digital representation of products
    • Product: How is the product going to be used digitally
    • Price: What is the effort/benefit for using the API?
    • Place: Making it easy to find and use the API
    • Promotion: Making sure developers know what the platform is offering


What: Products as APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): Making APIs the Default: Enabling Everybody to Think the API Way

(26) Expanded Product Marketing Mix: 7 Ps

  • Extends the 4 Ps [Product Marketing Mix: 4 Ps (1)] with a focus on services
  • Framework for decision-making for services marketing
    • People: Considerations regarding service consumers (UX/CX)
    • Process: Planning and managing service delivery
    • Physical Evidence: (Physical) context of service delivery
  • Applying the 7 P model to the digital representation of products
    • People: Creating team dynamics around the platform
    • Process: Analyze API consumption for improving APIs over time
    • Platform: Improve the platform as the virtual space for sharing APIs

How: API as a Product Erik Wilde (@dret): Making APIs the Default: Enabling Everybody to Think the API Way

(28) Value eats Design for Breakfast

  • API as a Product needs context because of its technical focus
    • Focus your energy on valuable APIs only
    • Managing bad APIs as a product will hardly improve their utility
  • Managing APIs as a product has two important axes
    • Product Iterations [Product Iterations (1)] must be managed so that products can be improved
    • Product Maturity [Product Maturity (1)] must be managed so that products can be matured and discontinued


How: API as a Product Erik Wilde (@dret): Making APIs the Default: Enabling Everybody to Think the API Way

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Making APIs the Default: Enabling Everybody to Think the API Way

(32) Doing the Right Thing

  • API Products are more product than they are API
    • The main focus is on creating and exposing something valuable
    • Value is defined by consumption which means focusing on users is important
    • Designing a good API is important but not the deciding factor
  • Doing the Right Thing vs. Doing the Thing Right
    • Doing the Right Thing → Identify capabilities and users as design foundations
    • Doing the Thing Right → Co-design API with users to create good DX


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Making APIs the Default: Enabling Everybody to Think the API Way
